definition: Ku Hung-ming or Gu Hongming (1857-1928), Malaysian man of letters, highly regarded for his literary works written mostly in English, and known for his monarchist views
crime/sin
surname Gu
eastern bean goose/great/large
to engrave/inscribed motto

sentences.english: Ku Hungming was a legendary figure in modern Chinese history.
sentences.chinese: 在中国近现代史上，辜鸿铭是一位相当奇特的人物。

definition: Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Liu Shipei (1884-1919), Chinese anarchist and revolutionary activist
Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Lin Shu (1852-1924), writer and influential translator and adaptor of vast swathes of Western literature into Classical Chinese
Liang Shuming (1893-1988), modern philosopher and teacher in the neo-Confucian tradition
William A.P. Martin (1827-1916), American missionary who lived 62 years in China between 1850 and 1916, and helped found many Chinese colleges, first president of Peking University
Feng Youlan (1895-1990), distinguished Chinese philosopher
Yuen Ren Chao (1892-1982), Chinese-American linguist
courtesy name of Lin Shu 林紓|林纾[Lin2 Shu1]

Zhou Zuoren (1885-1967), brother of Lu Xun 魯迅|鲁迅, academic in Japanese and Greek studies, briefly imprisoned after the war as Japanese collaborator, persecuted and died of unknown causes during the Cultural Revolution
ITŌ Hirobumi (1841-1909), Japanese Meiji restoration politician, prime minister on four occasions, influential in Japanese expansionism in Korea, assassinated in Harbin
Wu Tingfang (1842-1922), diplomat and lawyer
